children.subject:
As a background, I didn't take 126 or (obviously) 127 beforehand. You need to have a strong understanding of linear algebra and probability before coming in. It helps to understand matrix/vector probability stuff (multivariate gaussians, i.e. what are they and how do they work, whats a covariance matrix, etc.). Knowing a bit (very little) matrix/vector calculus will be helpful. 

Overall, just do the hws, read the notes and pay attention during the important parts of lecture.
Thank you so much for the tip! <3  I plan on taking 189 without taking 126 or 127 too, does cs70 cover the probability part of cs189?

No. You will need to be at an A/A+ level of understanding from CS70 and you will need to fill in some gaps, primarily with regards to random vectors, covariance matrices, MLE, MAP and multivariate gaussians.
If you're taking it with shewchuk I was in his peer advising, apparently for his version of the class 126 and 127 are not necessary.
Any tip on how you got an A in 189 ? :O

The consensus there was kinda split. Many said the course wasn't worthwhile because it glosses over the important parts (is that true for learning LP, QP, SOCP, Robust Optimization, i.e. the parts not covered in depth in 189?). Others said it was ok, and might be necessary for 227b and 227c. Do you think I'd be better off skipping 127 to take 227B and then 227C? I hear 127 and 227B have a lot of overlap.

I haven't taken 227 B/C, so I can't say anything definitively about that.

Like I said in that post, I don't think 127 in Spring 2018 dived into anything particularly deeply. At least the way they were presented in 127, the optimization problems of LP, QP, SOCP, and robust optimization all seemed relatively similar to each other. So learning all of them at 127-depth may not be as hard as it sounds.

If 227B does overlap with 127 a lot, then sounds like you might be ok skipping 127.

Hmm thats odd because it does seem like SOCP QP LP and robust optimization would be some of the most important parts of the course.

Did the class mostly go over the standard forms of each problem, examples of them, and how they relate (how QP and LP reduce to SOCP)? And did hws cover formulating each type of problem? Or was there actually emphasis on how these problems are solved (delving into methods like simplex, interior-point etc)?

I took 127 with El Ghaoui in Spring 2018, and I think the amount of depth that he went into could be covered in about a week. The class was webcasted when I took it, so you could probably find it.

The problem sets were more challenging, but the problems usually could be solved with some really weird hint they would reveal the day before homework was due, but the focus was on formulating each type of problems.

I don't recall them ever putting emphasis on how to solve LP, QP, and SOCP. On the homework, we always used a library to compute the final answer, and on the tests, they most they asked for was to "compute the dual problem." In the end, I don't think I got too much out of the class. However, the instructor is different for next semester. Maybe someone who took the class with Bayen last semester could answer?

If you have strong linear algebra background QP is really easy to learn. Just know positive definite, semidefinite matrices etc. SOCP and robust optimization are a bit more challenging, and I believe these topics are covered in more detail in 227B. This may be a bit too much of a tangent, but CS 270 also covers linear programming, semidefinite programming, weak duality + strong duality, gradient descent methods etc.
Take a look at @8385 for advice about taking 127 after 189.

history.content: I have the choice of taking CS 194 (cryptography) or EECS 127 next semester. I will be taking CS 162 and most likely CS 270 with one of those 2 courses (originally I wanted to take 182 but I was too far on the WL). I finished 189 this semester and got an A. Would taking 127 be worthwhile after finishing 189 with an A level understanding, or should I just self study the relevant parts (SOCP, QP, Robust Optimization, Duality/Lagrangians)? I may want to take 227B and 227C in the future, but I'm not sure. Would there be a significant increase in workload between either schedule?
history.subject: 127 or other classes post 189
